unnormalised: The construction of the new flyover on the Delhi-Jaipur highway is facing yet another delay, folks! Apparently, the 500 m long structure is now expected to be completed by Q4 2024, instead of the earlier deadline. Sources say the issue isn't the budget (a cool Rs. 75 crore already spent!), but the pesky matter of accurately measuring... well, everything.
normalised: The construction of the new flyover on the Delhi Jaipur highway is facing yet another delay, folks! Apparently, the five hundred meter long structure is now expected to be completed by Q four two thousand and twenty four, instead of the earlier deadline. Sources say the issue isn't the budget (a cool rupee seventy five crore already spent!), but the pesky matter of accurately measuring... well, everything.

unnormalised: One unnamed engineer (let's call him Rajesh, because why not?) claims that blueprints were initially drawn using a "traditional Indian measurement system" that involved hand spans and "a few gaj" estimated after a particularly strong chai. "Turns out," Rajesh chuckled, "a hand span isn't the most precise unit when you're dealing with 1000s of cubic meters of concrete!"
normalised: One unnamed engineer (let's call him Rajesh, because why not?) claims that blueprints were initially drawn using a "traditional Indian measurement system" that involved hand spans and "a few gaj" estimated after a particularly strong chai. "Turns out," Rajesh chuckled, "a hand span isn't the most precise unit when you're dealing with thousands of cubic meters of concrete!"

unnormalised: Adding to the chaos, a shipment of steel rods was reportedly delivered with lengths varying by up to 2 cm per rod. When questioned, the supplier blamed "monsoon humidity" for the discrepancies. Because, apparently, humidity can magically shrink or enlarge steel. The things you learn!
normalised: Adding to the chaos, a shipment of steel rods was reportedly delivered with lengths varying by up to two centimeter per rod. When questioned, the supplier blamed "monsoon humidity" for the discrepancies. Because, apparently, humidity can magically shrink or enlarge steel. The things you learn!

unnormalised: And then there's the infamous "sand saga." The sand meant to be used in the concrete mix was delivered... well, let's just say it had a few too many "natural additives," including a suspiciously large number of seashells. Now, I'm no construction expert, but I'm pretty sure seashells aren't ideal for load-bearing walls. The amount of sand was off too, by a whopping 20 tonnes.
normalised: And then there's the infamous "sand saga." The sand meant to be used in the concrete mix was delivered... well, let's just say it had a few too many "natural additives," including a suspiciously large number of seashells. Now, I'm no construction expert, but I'm pretty sure seashells aren't ideal for load bearing walls. The amount of sand was off too, by a whopping twenty tonnes.

unnormalised: So, the next time you're stuck in traffic near that perpetually unfinished flyover, just remember Rajesh and his hand spans, the monsoon-affected steel, and the seashell-infused sand. It's not just construction; it's an Indian Engineering Comedy, playing out in real-time! At least the tea is good. Estimated project end date: Maybe Diwali 2025? We shall see.
normalised: So, the next time you're stuck in traffic near that perpetually unfinished flyover, just remember Rajesh and his hand spans, the monsoon affected steel, and the seashell infused sand. It's not just construction; it's an Indian Engineering Comedy, playing out in real time! At least the tea is good. Estimated project end date: Maybe Diwali two thousand and twenty five? We shall see.
